articles.headline: In India, Grandma Cooks, They Deliver
articles.snippet: Delivery men called dabbawallas transport home-cooked meals to workplaces all over Mumbai, with near-clockwork precision.
articles.abstract: Delivery men called dabbawallas transport home-cooked meals to workplaces all over Mumbai, with near-clockwork precision.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — Gaurav Bamania, a hedge fund analyst who works in one of the many downtown office towers that now dominate the skyline of India’s financial capital, could easily eat lunch at one of the city’s better restaurants. Instead, Mr. Bamania, 26, follows a practice dating back over a century to the early years of British rule: he has a hot meal, lovingly cooked at home by his grandmother, and delivered to his desk every workday.

articles.headline: To Temper Image, Giuliani Trades Growl for Smile
articles.snippet: The Rudolph W. Giuliani on the campaign trail is a disciplined fellow who has abandoned his gruff tendencies.
articles.abstract: The Rudolph W. Giuliani on the campaign trail is a disciplined fellow who has abandoned his gruff tendencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Oh, baby, here it comes. The gray-haired woman raises her hand and compliments His Honor for his Sept. 11 bravery. Then she asks him:

articles.headline: Efficiency, Not Just Alternatives, Is Promoted as an Energy Saver
articles.snippet: Even supporters of alternative energy agree that the easiest way to cut carbon emissions and air pollution is to focus more on efficiency.
articles.abstract: Even supporters of alternative energy agree that the easiest way to cut carbon emissions and air pollution is to focus more on efficiency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WATERBURY, Vt. — Green Mountain Coffee Roasters makes a lot of money selling individual servings of ground coffee in white cups that are churned out by the millions from a hissing, clanking production line here. But it recently found a way to generate even greater profits from the operation that will require only a modest investment.

articles.headline: Bush to Tighten Fiscal Penalties Against Sudan
articles.snippet: President Bush will also press the U.N. for additional actions to end the violence in Darfur, officials said.
articles.abstract: President Bush will also press the U.N. for additional actions to end the violence in Darfur, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 28 — President Bush will announce Tuesday that he is imposing stiff economic sanctions against Sudan — including penalties against two senior government officials and a rebel leader — and that he will press the United Nations for additional actions to end the violence in Darfur, two senior administration officials said Monday.

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Wide-Eyed Over a Bride
articles.snippet: Anne Wojcicki has captured Silicon Valley’s attention with her marriage to a co-founder of Google, and with a biotech company she recently co-founded.
articles.abstract: Anne Wojcicki has captured Silicon Valley’s attention with her marriage to a co-founder of Google, and with a biotech company she recently co-founded.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sometimes good fortune arrives in fairytale-like flurries.

articles.headline: Desperate Iraqi Refugees Turn to Sex Trade in Syria
articles.snippet: As a group, prostitutes represent one of the most visible symptoms of an Iraqi refugee crisis that has exploded in Syria in recent months.
articles.abstract: As a group, prostitutes represent one of the most visible symptoms of an Iraqi refugee crisis that has exploded in Syria in recent months.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARABA, Syria — Back home in Iraq, Umm Hiba’s daughter was a devout schoolgirl, modest in her dress and serious about her studies. Hiba, who is now 16, wore the hijab, or Islamic head scarf, and rose early each day to say the dawn prayer before classes.

articles.headline: Big Landlord Close to Deal for a REIT in New York
articles.snippet: Tishman Speyer and Lehman Brothers are near a deal to buy Archstone-Smith Trust for more than $20 billion.
articles.abstract: Tishman Speyer and Lehman Brothers are near a deal to buy Archstone-Smith Trust for more than $20 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: The real estate company that bought two prominent apartment complexes on Manhattan’s Lower East Side is trying to make another major acquisition in the New York market.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Terry Pristin

articles.headline: Google Deal Said to Bring U.S. Scrutiny
articles.snippet: The F.T.C. has opened an antitrust investigation into Google’s planned $3.1 billion purchase of DoubleClick.
articles.abstract: The F.T.C. has opened an antitrust investigation into Google’s planned $3.1 billion purchase of DoubleClick.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission has opened a preliminary antitrust investigation into Google’s planned $3.1 billion purchase of the online advertising company DoubleClick, an industry executive briefed on the agency’s plans said yesterday.

articles.headline: Lawmakers Push for Big Subsidies for Coal Process
articles.snippet: The push for coal-to-liquid fuels reflects a tension between slowing global warming and cutting back on foreign oil.
articles.abstract: The push for coal-to-liquid fuels reflects a tension between slowing global warming and cutting back on foreign oil.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 28 — Even as Congressional leaders draft legislation to reduce greenhouse gases linked to global warming, a powerful roster of Democrats and Republicans is pushing to subsidize coal as the king of alternative fuels.

articles.headline: Digital Fears Emerge After Data Siege in Estonia
articles.snippet: The removal of a Soviet statue prompted cyberassaults that nearly shut down Estonia’s Internet infrastructure.
articles.abstract: The removal of a Soviet statue prompted cyberassaults that nearly shut down Estonia’s Internet infrastructure.
articles.lead_paragraph: TALLINN, Estonia, May 24 — When Estonian authorities began removing a bronze statue of a World War II-era Soviet soldier from a park in this bustling Baltic seaport last month, they expected violent street protests by Estonians of Russian descent.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and John Markoff
